natural problem: Let $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$. What is the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$?
natural solution: From here, it is clear that $f(101) = 101\cdot 100 + 2010$ and $f(100) = 100\cdot 99 + 2010$.

We now use the Euclidean algorithm. \begin{align} &\gcd(f(101), f(100)) \\ &= \gcd(101\cdot 100 + 2010, \, \, 100\cdot 99 + 2010) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 101\cdot 100 + 2010 - (100\cdot 99 + 2010)) \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
and h1 : "f 100 dvd f 101"
shows  "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$. What is the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 We can write $f(x) = x(x-1) + 2010$.
 From here, it is clear that $f(101) = 101\cdot 100 + 2010$ and $f(100) = 100\cdot 99 + 2010$.
 We now use the Euclidean algorithm. \begin{align} &\gcd(f(101), f(100)) \\ &= \gcd(101\cdot 100 + 2010, \, \, 100\cdot 99 + 2010) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 101\cdot 100 + 2010 - (100\cdot 99 + 2010)) \\
 &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2000 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 100\cdot 20 + 10, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 119 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\
 & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 59(2\cdot 100)) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 118\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100 + 10) \\ & = \gcd(200, \, \, 110) \\ & = \gcd(90, \, \, 110) \\
 & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90-4\cdot 20) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 10) \\ &= \boxed{10}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
and h1 : "f 100 dvd f 101"
shows  "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a function $f$ defined by $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$ for all integers $x$. If $f(100)$ divides $f(101)$, find the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$. The final answer is 10.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
shows  "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$. What is the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 We can write $f(x) = x(x-1) + 2010$.
 From here, it is clear that $f(101) = 101\cdot 100 + 2010$ and $f(100) = 100\cdot 99 + 2010$.
 We now use the Euclidean algorithm. \begin{align} &\gcd(f(101), f(100)) \\ &= \gcd(101\cdot 100 + 2010, \, \, 100\cdot 99 + 2010) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 101\cdot 100 + 2010 - (100\cdot 99 + 2010)) \\
 &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2000 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 100\cdot 20 + 10, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 119 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\
 & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 59(2\cdot 100)) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 118\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100 + 10) \\ & = \gcd(200, \, \, 110) \\ & = \gcd(90, \, \, 110) \\
 & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90-4\cdot 20) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 10) \\ &= \boxed{10}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
shows  "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the greatest common divisor of the two numbers obtained by evaluating the function $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$ at $x = 100$ and $x = 101$. The final answer is $10$.

 &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2000 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 100\cdot 20 + 10, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 119 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\

a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$. What is the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 We can write $f(x) = x(x-1) + 2010$.
 From here, it is clear that $f(101) = 101\cdot 100 + 2010$ and $f(100) = 100\cdot 99 + 2010$.
 We now use the Euclidean algorithm. \begin{align} &\gcd(f(101), f(100)) \\ &= \gcd(101\cdot 100 + 2010, \, \, 100\cdot 99 + 2010) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 101\cdot 100 + 2010 - (100\cdot 99 + 2010)) \\
 &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2000 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 100\cdot 20 + 10, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 119 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\
 & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 59(2\cdot 100)) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 118\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100 + 10) \\ & = \gcd(200, \, \, 110) \\ & = \gcd(90, \, \, 110) \\

 *)

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
and h1 : "f 100 = a"
and h2 : "f 101 = b"
and h3 : "gcd a b = c"
shows  "c = 10"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$. What is the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 We can write $f(x) = x(x-1) + 2010$.
 From here, it is clear that $f(101) = 101\cdot 100 + 2010$ and $f(100) = 100\cdot 99 + 2010$.
 We now use the Euclidean algorithm. \begin{align} &\gcd(f(101), f(100)) \\ &= \gcd(101\cdot 100 + 2010, \, \, 100\cdot 99 + 2010) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 101\cdot 100 + 2010 - (100\cdot 99 + 2010)) \\
 &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2000 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 100\cdot 20 + 10, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 119 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\
 & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 59(2\cdot 100)) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 118\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100 + 10) \\ & = \gcd(200, \, \, 110) \\ & = \gcd(90, \, \, 110) \\
 & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90-4\cdot 20) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 10) \\ &= \boxed{10}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
and h1 : "f 100 = a"
and h2 : "f 101 = b"
and h3 : "gcd a b = c"
shows  "c = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: The function $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$ is given. If $f(100) = a$ and $f(101) = b$, find the greatest common divisor (gcd) of $a$ and $b$. The final answer is $10$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
shows  "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$. What is the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 We can write $f(x) = x(x-1) + 2010$.
 From here, it is clear that $f(101) = 101\cdot 100 + 2010$ and $f(100) = 100\cdot 99 + 2010$.
 We now use the Euclidean algorithm. \begin{align} &\gcd(f(101), f(100)) \\ &= \gcd(101\cdot 100 + 2010, \, \, 100\cdot 99 + 2010) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 101\cdot 100 + 2010 - (100\cdot 99 + 2010)) \\
 &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2000 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 100\cdot 20 + 10, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 119 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\
 & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 59(2\cdot 100)) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 118\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100 + 10) \\ & = \gcd(200, \, \, 110) \\ & = \gcd(90, \, \, 110) \\
 & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90-4\cdot 20) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 10) \\ &= \boxed{10}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
shows  "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
shows  "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$. What is the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 We can write $f(x) = x(x-1) + 2010$.
 From here, it is clear that $f(101) = 101\cdot 100 + 2010$ and $f(100) = 100\cdot 99 + 2010$.
 We now use the Euclidean algorithm. \begin{align} &\gcd(f(101), f(100)) \\ &= \gcd(101\cdot 100 + 2010, \, \, 100\cdot 99 + 2010) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 101\cdot 100 + 2010 - (100\cdot 99 + 2010)) \\
 &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2000 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 100\cdot 20 + 10, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 119 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\
 & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 59(2\cdot 100)) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 118\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100 + 10) \\ & = \gcd(200, \, \, 110) \\ & = \gcd(90, \, \, 110) \\
 & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90-4\cdot 20) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 10) \\ &= \boxed{10}. \end{align}
 *)

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = x^2 - x + 2010"
and h1 : "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
shows  "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$. What is the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 We can write $f(x) = x(x-1) + 2010$.
 From here, it is clear that $f(101) = 101\cdot 100 + 2010$ and $f(100) = 100\cdot 99 + 2010$.
 We now use the Euclidean algorithm. \begin{align} &\gcd(f(101), f(100)) \\ &= \gcd(101\cdot 100 + 2010, \, \, 100\cdot 99 + 2010) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 101\cdot 100 + 2010 - (100\cdot 99 + 2010)) \\
 &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2000 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 100\cdot 20 + 10, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 119 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\
 & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 59(2\cdot 100)) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 118\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100 + 10) \\ & = \gcd(200, \, \, 110) \\ & = \gcd(90, \, \, 110) \\
 & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90-4\cdot 20) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 10) \\ &= \boxed{10}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = x^2 - x + 2010"
and h1 : "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
shows  "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If a function $f$ is defined for all integers $x$ as $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$, and the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$ is 10, then confirm that the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$ is indeed 10.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
and h1 : "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
shows  "True"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$. What is the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 We can write $f(x) = x(x-1) + 2010$.
 From here, it is clear that $f(101) = 101\cdot 100 + 2010$ and $f(100) = 100\cdot 99 + 2010$.
 We now use the Euclidean algorithm. \begin{align} &\gcd(f(101), f(100)) \\ &= \gcd(101\cdot 100 + 2010, \, \, 100\cdot 99 + 2010) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 101\cdot 100 + 2010 - (100\cdot 99 + 2010)) \\
 &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2000 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 100\cdot 20 + 10, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 119 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\
 & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 59(2\cdot 100)) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 118\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100 + 10) \\ & = \gcd(200, \, \, 110) \\ & = \gcd(90, \, \, 110) \\
 & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90-4\cdot 20) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 10) \\ &= \boxed{10}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
and h1 : "gcd (f 100) (f 101) = 10"
shows  "True"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: If $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$, find the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$. The result should be $10$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int ⇒ int"
assumes h0 : "∀x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
and h1 : "∃d. d = gcd (f 100) (f 101)"
shows  "d = 10"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$. What is the greatest common divisor of $f(100)$ and $f(101)$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 We can write $f(x) = x(x-1) + 2010$.
 From here, it is clear that $f(101) = 101\cdot 100 + 2010$ and $f(100) = 100\cdot 99 + 2010$.
 We now use the Euclidean algorithm. \begin{align} &\gcd(f(101), f(100)) \\ &= \gcd(101\cdot 100 + 2010, \, \, 100\cdot 99 + 2010) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 101\cdot 100 + 2010 - (100\cdot 99 + 2010)) \\
 &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2010, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ &= \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 2000 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 99 + 100\cdot 20 + 10, 2\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(100\cdot 119 + 10, \, \, 2\cdot 100) \\
 & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 59(2\cdot 100)) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100\cdot 119 + 10 - 118\cdot 100) \\ & = \gcd(2\cdot 100, \, \, 100 + 10) \\ & = \gcd(200, \, \, 110) \\ & = \gcd(90, \, \, 110) \\
 & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 90-4\cdot 20) \\ & = \gcd(20, \, \, 10) \\ &= \boxed{10}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int ⇒ int"
assumes h0 : "∀x. f x = x powr 2 - x + 2010"
and h1 : "∃d. d = gcd (f 100) (f 101)"
shows  "d = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Determine the greatest common divisor (gcd) of the results of the function $f(x) = x^2 - x + 2010$ evaluated at $x = 100$ and $x = 101$. The final answer is $10$.
